messages.message:
just in case others encounter this issue - when i restart `file-service`with different aws credentials, i see the new environment variable values reflected in `core-services/file-service/tmp/docker_env_local.list` but somehow they're not getting used in `file-service` immediately

for some reason, i need to restart `file-service` several times (over 2 hours) for the new environment variables ot be used - maybe the results for the aws s3 calls are getting cached in `redis`? next time i'll try to restart `redis` as well to see if that solves the issue
@Sayan was this issue you said you had to fully kill file-service for?
potentially, I have found that doing `pkill -f file-service` and restarting it solves `file-service` issues most times
hmm `pkill -f file-service` should only be helpful if you're running file-service locally (not in Docker) on your laptop though

i just figured out the correct sequence of actions to fix this!
• `cs stop file-service`
• `cs stop core-platform`
• flushall in redis (https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C05L87V014J/p1733345534501089?thread_ts=1733242246.041289&cid=C05L87V014J)
• `cs start file-service`
• `cs start core-platform`
